Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogenetic community ecology and diversification of hyperoliid frogs in the Afrotropics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The lowland rainforests and montane forests of Africa are rich with biodiversity, but little is known about the ecological processes that have produced this high diversity. There is considerable debate about whether these different forest habitats are generating or maintaining diversity, and what ecological factors limit the number of species found in a given area. It has been proposed that the historically stable lowland rainforests of West Africa act to sustain old diversity, whereas the environmentally fluctuating montane forests of East Africa promote speciation and the generation of new diversity. This project tests that hypothesis using Hyperoliid frogs, which are Africa?s most diverse frog family, exhibiting the highest species richness in forested regions. The research will examine the factors promoting diversity by studying the number of species of hyperoliid frogs found in a given forest community, quantifying how ecologically similar those species are to one another, and determining the evolutionary relationships and ages of the species in the community. Comparing hyperoliid frog communities distributed across similar biogeographic regions as well across different kinds of forests, such as high elevation mountain forests and lowland rainforests, can uncover large-scale patterns of diversification in tropical Africa.

Frogs have been used as indicator species, whose presence or absence in an environment provides an assessment of the environmental integrity. The threat of large-scale deforestation is immediate for most African countries, and habitat alteration will negatively impact the large numbers of forest dwelling species. By characterizing communities of hyperoliid frogs in different biogeographic regions in Africa, this study will establish a baseline for future monitoring and conservation efforts. Large-scale research across many African countries is both logistically and financially demanding, and therefore it is critical to establish and facilitate interactions within the community of researchers working in Africa. This project is the result of a major collaborative effort among over 22 researchers working in research institutions or universities located in the US, Europe, and Africa, and brings together a diverse group of researchers that will facilitate future cooperative efforts on similar projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Daniel Portik has completed research for his dissertation “Diversification of hyperoliid reed frogs across the Afrotropics” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During the funding period, Dan participated in several field expeditions to Africa and completed molecular lab work for his project, particularly high-throughput DNA sequencing. His academic work is generally focused on identifying amphibian and reptile biodiversity across West and Central Africa, with the goal of understanding which ecological processes or group-specific characteristics generate and maintain this diversity. This is accomplished with the aid of new DNA sequencing technologies to facilitate discovery of new species and to establish evolutionary relationships among described species.

 

There are over 800 species of frogs across Africa, with over half of these species belonging to a single clade called the Afrobatrachia. This group is ecologically diverse and composed of four major families. The relationships among these families and their respective genera are now established based on molecular data generated during this project. Divergence dating estimates indicate the most species-rich genera began to diversify rapidly during the Early Miocene, resulting in the formation of over 250 species. One Afrobatrachian family, the Hyperoliidae, has presented substantial taxonomic difficulties and due to the patterns of rapid diversification the relationships within this family have been difficult to resolve. Using a newly developed method of DNA capture and sequencing, termed transcriptome-based exon capture, Dan has successfully targeted and sequenced several thousand nuclear genes for 260 hyperoliid frogs. These data will be used to reconstruct the phylogenetic and evolutionary relationships among species in this diverse family. With these relationships established, Dan will complete his dissertation research by studying the evolution of sexual dichromatism, sexual size dimorphism, and community phenotypes among the hyperoliid reed frogs. These frogs display several unique characteristics, including different color patterns between the sexes, and they tend to dominate frog communities both in terms of abundance and species richness. The overall goal of the research on hyperoliid frogs is to begin to understand large-scale patterns of diversification across tropical Africa.

 

This project has resulted in the lab training of several graduate and undergraduate researchers and resulted in the establishment of publicly available bioinformatics pipelines for data analysis. The molecular methods for this project were developed in the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology, and continue to serve as a foundation for similar projects being conducted by other faculty and students.

 

During the Summer of 2014, Dan participated in the African Amphibian Working Group meetings in Bwindi, Uganda. He presented the new molecular data collection technique to experts and students in his field, which can be applied to any understudied taxonomic group. The technique allows the rapid advance of knowledge for assessing levels of biodiversity and reconstructing the evolutionary relationships of the focal group. During these meetings Dan helped to train a number of African students on specimen preparation and basic museum science. Dan also continued to build collaborative relationships with students and top scientists, and the hyperoliid project now includes over 30 international collaborators. This collaboration has ensured the success of his project and will continue to advance the field of African herpetology. Dan will continue disseminating his research through several regional and international society meetings over the next year.
